instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Hi there. This Macbook came in with no power. Stuck at 5V on both USB-C ports and hovers between 40mA and 26mA, never gets to 20V. . I believe it was a cheap power cable that caused this.

Board is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing, all other necessary voltages appear to be present. There are no shorts on any main power lines.

I have replaced:

Both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s
Both <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> & <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>
<CHIP>U8210</CHIP>
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (twice)

Checked all resistors around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and all seem within spec.

Please help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Inspect USB-C redriver chip for damage; does it get hot?

Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage; diode mode to ground, if no voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
No heat on redriver chip.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.061V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.402V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> diode reading is 0.438

Replaced the redriver chip anyway and no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> level.
Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/<SIGNAL>B_MON</SIGNAL>.

Remove F7000 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

Did you test with good battery (holding some charge)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> = 3.401
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> = 5.194
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 1.290
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> = 0V
VDDA = 5.109
VDDP = 5.109
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_R_L</SIGNAL> = 3.410
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> = 3.410
<SIGNAL>A_MON</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>B_MON</SIGNAL> = 0V

Attempting to connect a known good battery causes there to be no activity on charger. Tried two different batteries. As soon as battery is disconnected, charger turns on to 5V 0A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
What voltages do you get on the board when battery is connected?
Any reaction if you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
